H0.text: Averaging the amount of rain that fell during a lightning storm is the best way to determine whether storms with lightning produce more rain than storms without lightning.

H1.text: Counting the number of lightning strikes during a one‑hour period is the best way to answer a student’s question about whether storms with lightning produce more rain than storms without lightning.

H2.text: Recording rainfall amounts in storms with and without lightning is the best way for a student to determine whether storms with lightning produce more rain than storms without lightning.

H3.text: Calculating the number of fires that are caused by lightning strikes is the best way for a student to determine whether storms with lightning produce more rain than storms without lightning.

A4.text: A rain gauge (also known as udometer, ombrometer, pluviometer and hyetometer) is an instrument used by meteorologists and hydrologists to gather and measure the amount of liquid precipitation in a predefined area, over a set period of time.

A5.text: Tipping buckets also tend to underestimate the amount of rainfall, particularly in snowfall and heavy rainfall events.
